The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  1.0561943  1.1099260 20.2518793  7.5725271  0.5023763  6.1327905
#>  [7]  4.0673551  0.4886219  0.7032099  0.9311428
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1]  0.4740408 33.1978203  0.3609233  0.5930011  1.8972267  0.3889576
#>  [7]  0.4118381  1.1107626  0.7951931  0.2805136
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1]  0.09596928 12.41742500  0.70861333  4.53582383  0.09586247  0.91776737
#>  [7]  0.72184997  0.10512321  0.35418787  0.83372464
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.2673295 0.6568766 3.6877805 0.4020808 1.0997088 0.4686355 1.0011067
#>  [8] 0.4016013 0.1972264 0.5487377
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1] 0.20348825 0.06241537 0.63219415 0.13138946 0.25359590 0.74711023
#>  [7] 0.09862263 0.23731597 0.45023838 1.71502362
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
